{{DISPLAYTITLE:Publication history of ''The Ego and Its Own''}} [[File:Ein1844v2.png|thumb|Cover of the [[German language]] first edition, published in Leipzig in 1844.]] ''[[The Ego and Its Own]]'' ({{lang-de|Der Einzige und sein Eigentum}}) is a [[philosophy|philosophical]] work by [[German language|German]] philosopher [[Max Stirner]] (1806-1856), first published in 1844.
==First editions== [[File:The Ego and Its Own - Tsuji Jun translation.jpg|thumb|right|Cover of Tsuji Jun's Japanese first edition (1920)]] ===Original in German=== * The original [[German language|German]] edition appeared in October 1844 in [[Leipzig]]. ===Translations (chronologically)=== * [[French language|French]] (''L'unique et sa propriété'', 1899), * [[Danish language|Danish]] (''Den Eneste og hans Ejendom'', 1901), * [[Spanish language|Spanish]] (''El único y su propiedad'', 1901), * [[Italian language|Italian]] (''L'unico e la sua proprietà'', 1902), * [[Russian language|Russian]] (''Edinstvennyj i ego dostojanie'', 1906), * [[English language|English]] (''The Ego and His Own'', 1907), * [[Dutch language|Dutch]] (''De Eenige en z'n Eigendom'', 1907), * [[Swedish language|Swedish]] (''Den ende och hans egendom'', 1910), * [[Japanese language|Japanese]] (''Yuiitsusha to sono shoyû'', 1920), * [[Serbo-croatian language|Serbo-Croatian]] (''Jedini i njegovo vlastništvo'', 1976), * [[Catalan language|Catalan]] (''L'únic i la seva propietat'', 1986). * [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] (''Az egyetlen és tulajdona'', 1991). (Second part only) * [[Greek language|Greek]] (''O μοναδικός και το δικό του'', 2002), * [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] (''O Único e a sua propriedade'', 2004), * [[Polish language|Polish]] (''Jedyny i jego własność'', 2005), * [[Czech language|Czech]] (''Jediný a jeho vlastnictví'', 2010).
==English editions== [[File:Den ende.png|thumb|right|''Den ende och hans egendom'' – a 1911 Swedish edition, with a foreword by [[Georg Brandes]] and afterword by [[Albert Jensen (anarchist)|Albert Jensen]].]] ===First edition (1907)=== * The first English Language Edition appeared in 1907; it was a translation by the [[United States|American]] [[individualist anarchism|individualist anarchist]], [[Steven T. Byington]] with an introduction by [[James L. Walker]]. The publisher was [[Benjamin R. Tucker]], [[New York City]]. This edition was reprinted several times by several publishers in New York and [[London]] up to 1931.
===Libertarian Book Club edition (1963)=== * The 1963 [[Libertarian Book Club]] edition is a re-print of the 1907 Byington translation. Edited by [[James J. Martin]] and with a cover by the son of [[Rudolf Rocker]], the edition revived interest in Stirner as an influence on [[anarchism]] and related ideologies and brought [[Max Stirner]] to a wider audience in the [[English-speaking world]]. This edition was reprinted several times by several publishers in the [[United States]] and [[United Kingdom]] up to 1993, sometimes with a preface by Sidney E. Parker.
===Harper & Row - Readings in Fascist, Racist and Elitist Ideology (1971)=== * An [[abridged]] English edition of the Byington translation revised, selected and annotated by John Carroll. [[New York City]] / [[London]]: [[Harper & Row]] 1971. 266 pp. The book appeared in a series "Roots of the Right. Readings in [[Fascist]], [[Racist]] and [[Elitist]] [[Ideology]]", together with writings by [[Gobineau]], [[Alfred Rosenberg]], [[Joseph de Maistre|de Maistre]], [[Maurras]]. The text consists of a mix of about a hundred quotations from ''The Ego'' (and some from Stirner's minor writings), reducing the volume by about a half. The reason why Stirner's work was selected for this series remains unclear given the book's fierce anti-authoritarianism and emphasis on the sovereignty of the individual.
===Rebel Press edition (1993)=== * The 1993 Rebel Press, [[London]] edition is an unabridged republication of the 1963 re-print of the 1907 Byington translation by the Libertarian Book Club. The Rebel Press, [[London]] edition has a cover design from [[anarchist]] [[artist]] and [[cartoonist]], [[Clifford Harper]] and a preface by Sidney E. Parker.
===Cambridge University press edition (1995)=== * The [[Cambridge University]] press edition (ed. David Leopold, 1995) is a revised version of the original 1907 Byington translation with a new introduction by David Leopold. Leopold changed the title (His to Its) "not out of ahistorical considerations of 'political correctness' but because [[Stirner]] clearly identifies the egoistic subject as prior to gender" (p. xl). While Leopold accepted the Byington translation as "an heroic attempt to convey the readable yet idiosyncratic prose of [[Stirner]]'s original", he "made a number of amendments, such as removing infelicities and archaisms, replacing the occasional missing sentence, and restoring some of the original paragraph and sections breaks." (p. xxxix)
===Underworld Amusements edition (2017)=== * [[Individualist Anarchism|Individual Anarchist]] writer and historian Wolfi Landstreicher began his completely new translation in 2010, and published under the more literal title of "The Unique and Its Property." All prior published editions had been reproductions of, or based on the Byington translation, but Landstreicher's work constitutes the second full translation ever completed. He also wrote an introduction to it.
== Other language editions ==
===German=== *''Der Einzige und sein Eigenthum.'' Leipzig: Otto Wigand 1845 [Oct. 1844] (original, [[First_edition#First_edition|first edition]]) *''Der Einzige und sein Eigenthum.'' 2. Auflage. Leipzig: Otto Wigand 1882 *''Der Einzige und sein Eigentum.'' Einführung Paul Lauterbach. Leipzig: Reclams Universalbibliothek 1893ff *''Der Einzige und sein Eigentum.'' 3. Auflage. Leipzig: Otto Wigand 1901 *several editions in the 1920s by various publishers *''Der Einzige und sein Eigentum.'' Nachwort Ahlrich Meyer. Stuttgart: Reclams Universalbibliothek 1972ff *several editions (some abridged) since 1968 by various publishers
===French=== *{{cite book|title=L'unique et sa propriété |location=Paris |publisher=P.-V. Stock |year=1899| oclc=37909006}} *{{cite book|title=L'unique et sa propriété |editor=Robert L Reclaire |type=Microfilm |location=Paris |publisher=P.V. Stock |year=1900 |oclc=24025908}} *{{cite book|title=L'unique et sa propriété |location=Paris |publisher=Éditions Stock |year=1978 |isbn=2-234-00812-3 |oclc=20116578}}
===Russian=== *{{cite book|title=Edinstvennyĭ i ego dostojanie |location=Moscow |publisher=V.M. Sadlina |year=1907 |oclc=45359741}} *{{cite book|title=Edinstvennyĭ i ego sobstvennostʹ |location=Saint Petersburg |publisher=Biblioteka "Svi︠e︡tocha" |year=1907 |edition=Izd. kommentirovannoe |OCLC=16165785}} *{{cite book|title=Edinstvennyĭ i ego dostojanie |location=Saint Petersburg |publisher=Tip. "Sirīus" |year=1910 |oclc=241310993}} *{{cite book|title=Edinstvennyĭ i ego sobstvennostʹ |editor=M Kronenberg |location=[[Paul Avrich Collection]] ([[Library of Congress]]) |publisher=Izd. "Rabochee kn-vo" |year=1922|oclc=32203218}} *{{cite book|title=Edinstvennyĭ i ego sobstvennostʹ |location=Kharkov |publisher=Osnova |year=1994 |isbn=5-7768-0265-2 |oclc=32896618}}
==Online editions== {{wikisource|The Ego and Its Own|''The Ego and Its Own''}} * [http://www.lsr-projekt.de/msee.html ''Der Einzige und sein Eigenthum''], original German, with concordance of three editions. * [http://www.lsr-projekt.de/poly/enee.html ''The Ego and Its Own''], English, based on Tucker's edition, with concordance of three editions. * [http://www.df.lth.se/~triad/stirner/ Electronic text versions of the book] * [http://www.lsr-projekt.de/poly/enrec.html Stirner's Critics] - Stirner's reply to his critics, bilingual (addendum to ''The Ego'')
{{Einzige}}

{{Infobox artwork | image_file = Winslow Homer - Right and Left.jpg | painting_alignment = right | image_size = 300px | title = Right and Left | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Winslow Homer]] | year = {{start date|1909}} | medium = [[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | height_metric = 71.8 | width_metric = 122.9 | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | metric_unit = cm | city = [[Washington, D.C.]] | museum = [[National Gallery of Art]] | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the exact coordinates of the artwork itself (and only where known) and not for the coordinates of the museum. Leave blank if coordinates are not known. --> | owner = }}
'''''Right and Left''''' is a 1909 oil on canvas painting by the American artist [[Winslow Homer]]. It depicts a pair of [[common goldeneye]] ducks at the moment they are hit by a hunter's shotgun blast as they attempt to take flight. Completed less than two years before his death, it was Homer's last great painting,<ref name="C3">Cikovsky, 374</ref> and has been the subject of a variety of interpretations regarding its origin, composition and meaning. As with his other late masterworks, it represents a return to the sporting and hunting subjects of Homer's earlier years, and was to be his final engagement with the theme. Its design recalls that of [[Japanese art]], and the composition resembles that of a colored engraving by [[John James Audubon]].
==Background== In May 1908 Homer suffered temporary impairment of his speech and muscular control as the effects of a mild stroke; on June 4 he wrote his brother Charles that "I can paint as well as ever. I think my pictures better for having one eye in the pot and one eye up a chimney— a new departure in the art world."<ref>Cikovsky, 405</ref> By July 18 he was able to write that he had regained his abilities with the exception of tying "my neck tie in the way that I have done for the past 20 years....Every four or five days I try to do it but....it has been of no use."<ref>Cooper, 238-239</ref> Although he never completely recovered, Homer was well enough to attempt a major work, and it is probably ''Right and Left'' that he referred to in a letter to his brother Charles dated December 8, 1908: "I am painting when it is light enough on a most surprising picture".<ref name="C5">Cikovsky, 375</ref><ref>Cikovsky, 406</ref>
[[File:A Good Shot by Winslow Homer, 1892.png|thumb|left|Winslow Homer. ''A Good Shot, Adirondacks'', 1892. Watercolor. National Gallery of Art. With the hunter a distant element and the stricken animal placed in the foreground, this watercolor anticipates the composition of ''Right and Left''.<ref name="CO">Cooper, 184</ref>]]
Homer's biographers offer varying accounts of the events surrounding both the painting's conception and initial development. Homer's first biographer, William Howe Downes, wrote that the ducks used for the painting had been purchased by the artist for his Thanksgiving dinner; he so admired their [[plumage]] that he painted them instead.<ref name="C2">Cikovsky, 388</ref> Homer's nephew told another of Homer's biographers, Philip Beam, that a friend of the artist named Phineas W. Sprague shot the birds in [[Prouts Neck]] that autumn and hung them on Homer's studio door, and the arrangement inspired the painting's design.<ref name="C2">Cikovsky, 388</ref> Given the goldeneye's taste— Audubon called the duck "fishy, and in my opinion unfit for being eaten"— insofar as the implication is that the ducks were intended for food, neither story is altogether credible.<ref name="C2">Cikovsky, 388</ref>
Likewise there are different versions regarding Homer's preparatory methods. Downes recounted that Homer took to sea in a boat, accompanied by a man with a [[double-barreled shotgun]], and studied the movements of birds as they were shot.<ref name="C2">Cikovsky, 388</ref> In Beam's telling, Homer stood atop a cliff at [[Prouts Neck, Maine|Prouts Neck]] while his neighbor [[William Googins|Will Googins]], fired blank charges in his direction from a rowboat offshore.<ref name="C2">Cikovsky, 388</ref> However, Homer was already familiar with this angle of shotgun blast, having in 1864 painted ''Defiance'', a [[American Civil War|Civil War]] subject of a soldier being shot at, and in 1892 ''A Good Shot, Adirondacks'', which shows the puff of distant rifle smoke and a mortally wounded deer hit in the foreground;<ref name="C2">Cikovsky, 388</ref> the latter especially anticipates the composition and intent of ''Right and Left''.<ref name="CO">Cooper, 184</ref>
==Painting== For its "restrained color and extraordinary composition" the painting's debt to Japanese art has been noted by art historians.<ref name="C3">Cikovsky, 374</ref><ref>Gardner, 206</ref><ref name="C4">Cikovsky, 389</ref> It has been compared to avian subjects by [[Okyo Maruyama]], [[Hiroshige]], and [[Hokusai]], and was included in a major ''[[Japonisme]]'' exhibition in Paris in 1988.<ref name="C4">Cikovsky, 389</ref> As well, it resembles John James Audubon's plate ''Golden-Eye Duck''.<ref name="C3">Cikovsky, 374</ref>
[[File:342 Golden-Eye Duck.jpg|thumb|[[John James Audubon]], ''Golden-Eye Duck'']]
Against the tradition of birds painted as dead [[still life]] objects, ''Right and Left'' is unique for its depiction of the very moment of death.<ref name="L">[https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/great-works/homer-winslow-right-and-left-1907-744413.html Lubbock]</ref> Despite their rapid movement, the birds are seen as if frozen in a snapshot, and the viewer is literally afforded a bird's eye view, in the line of the hunter's fire.<ref name="L"/> Though the painting represents violent action, its formal aesthetic is that of sharply focused detachment,<ref name="L"/> and has been described by Nicolai Cikovsky, Jr. of the [[National Gallery of Art]] as "a staggeringly beautiful and almost oriental arrangement of birds--just abstract shapes against bands of the subtlest cream and grey".<ref>[http://www.nga.gov/collection/rightandleft.shtm National Gallery of Art] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101105050836/http://www.nga.gov/collection/rightandleft.shtm |date=2010-11-05 }}</ref>
The design consists of four horizontal bands of sea and sky which are connected by a series of vertical and diagonal shapes formed by the ducks' bodies— the one at left (male) struggling to ascend, its partner in a similar position but turned 90 degrees, already falling limp— and wave crests.<ref name="COO">Cooke, 118</ref> Additionally, the birds' webbed feet and beaks and the boat's bow repeat the jagged contours of the waves.<ref name="COO">Cooke, 118</ref> Half hidden, the hunters occupy an ambiguous position, and it is uncertain whether the line above them denotes the horizon or a fog bank.<ref name="COO">Cooke, 118</ref> Atop this line is the rim of the sun, depicted as a red sliver.<ref name="COO">Cooke, 118</ref> At the right is a stray feather which "serves as an exclamation point for the whole composition."<ref name="COO">Cooke, 118</ref>
The painting was received by [[Knoedler|Knoedler & Co.]] gallery in New York by January 30, 1909, and was described by the gallery as ''The Golden Eye or Whistler Duck''.<ref name="C4">Cikovsky, 389</ref> According to Downes the painting was initially exhibited without Homer's having titled it, and received its name from a hunter who shouted appreciatively "Right and left!", the term for a rifleman's accomplishment in taking down two birds in quick succession with a double-barreled shotgun.<ref name="C2">Cikovsky, 388</ref><ref>[http://www.nga.gov/fcgi-bin/tinfo_f?object=39763&detail=none National Gallery of Art] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101110062726/http://www.nga.gov/fcgi-bin/tinfo_f?object=39763&detail=none |date=2010-11-10 }}</ref> Upon viewing the painting in New York, its first owner, Randal Morgan, asked several questions regarding Homer's intent: he inquired as to the direction of the largest wave, and the cause of the disturbance in the water at the front of the picture, which he believed was the impetus for the ducks' movement to leave their feeding.<ref name="C4">Cikovsky, 389</ref> The questions were forwarded to the artist, but his reply is unknown. On August 3, 1909 Morgan bought the painting for $5,000, $4,000 of which went to Homer.<ref name="C4">Cikovsky, 389</ref>
==Meaning== Although it is a painting of a sporting subject, and thus was part of a popular anecdotal tradition, given both the violence of the subject and the fact that it was painted the year before Homer's death, ''Right and Left'' has invited metaphysical interpretation.<ref name="C4">Cikovsky, 389</ref><ref>Cikovsky, 374-375</ref> For art historian [[John Wilmerding]], the painting embodied "a sense of the momentary and the universal, mortality illuminated by showing these creatures at the juncture of life and death".<ref name="C4">Cikovsky, 389</ref> It represents the summation of Homer's sporting pictures, and presents its subject with an "almost testamentary finality".<ref name="C3">Cikovsky, 374</ref>
It has also been suggested that in addition to summarizing interests that were lifelong for Homer, as well as referring to the works of previous artists, a modern and ironic meaning may have been intended as well: in 1908 air travel was a novel and transforming human achievement, one fraught with the adventure and danger of flight.<ref name="C5">Cikovsky, 375</ref> Considering his worldly and pictorial intelligence, it is possible that Homer intended ''Right and Left'' as an oblique reference to this aspect of modern life.<ref name="C5">Cikovsky, 375</ref>

[[File:RDS Logo.png|thumb|Royal Drawing School]] The '''Royal Drawing School''' is an educational organisation and [[Charitable organization#Charity registration|registered charity]]<ref>{{EW charity|1101538}}</ref> in the [[London Borough of Hackney]] in [[England]]. It was founded in 2000 by the [[Charles, Prince of Wales|Prince of Wales]] as '''The Prince's Drawing School''' and received its current name in 2014.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Knox|first1=James|title=Royal Drawing School receives official title from The Queen|url=http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Royal-Drawing-School-receives-official-title-from-The-Queen/36287|accessdate=19 November 2014|work=[[The Art Newspaper]]|date=18 November 2014}}</ref>
The aim of the Royal Drawing School is to raise the standard and profile of drawing through teaching and practice. It is one of only a few institutions in the world offering in-depth, quality tuition for those who wish to develop their observational drawing skills.
As well as a Postgraduate Programme, the School runs a broad range of affordable courses designed for both professional artists and other interested adults, including master classes in the life room, in museums and galleries and in the streets and parks of [[London]]. Drawing instruction is delivered by distinguished artists and teachers from leading institutions including the [[Royal Academy Schools]], [[Central Saint Martins]], the [[Royal College of Art]] and the [[Slade School of Fine Art|Slade]]. Over 3,000 students have attended classes since 2000; there are over 130 alumni of the Postgraduate Programme.{{Update inline|date=August 2018}} The School, founded by the Prince of Wales, is based on the top floor of a converted warehouse in [[Shoreditch]], an area rich in galleries and design studios.
The School also aims to make it possible for every child with an aptitude for drawing to achieve their potential. The School provides serious, sustained tuition and mentoring, for children aged 10–14, from all backgrounds, through affordable programmes which are provided when and where it works for students.
The Royal Drawing School is part of [[The Prince's Charities]], a group of not-for-profit organizations of which the Prince of Wales is President: 17 of the 19 charities were founded personally by the Prince.
In 2006, The Prince's Drawing School received a donation of £85,000 from [[The Prince's Charities Foundation]].
In 2018, works created by The Royal Drawing School and two other charities founded by Prince Charles were put on display during the Prince & Patron exhibition to mark his 70th birthday.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.royalcollection.org.uk/collection/themes/exhibitions/prince-patron/buckingham-palace|title=Prince & Patron|publisher=Royal Collection Trust|accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.princeofwales.gov.uk/prince-patron-exhibition-unveiled-buckingham-palace|title=Prince & Patron exhibition unveiled at Buckingham Palace|publisher=The Prince of Wales|date=20 July 2018|accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref>
== Sites and collaborations == The Royal Drawing School has five campuses across London; in Shoreditch, [[Oxford Street]], South Kensington and Trinity Buoy Wharf. The School also collaborates with a number of institutions including [[National Gallery|The National Gallery]], [[British Museum|The British Museum]], [[Royal Academy of Arts]], [[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Portrait Gallery]], [[Victoria and Albert Museum|V&A]] and the [[Saatchi Gallery]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://royaldrawingschool.org/about/facilities/|title=Facilities {{!}} The Royal Drawing School|website=The Royal Drawing School|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://royaldrawingschool.org/about/educational-partners/|title=Educational Partners {{!}} The Royal Drawing School|website=The Royal Drawing School|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref>

page.title: Saint Francis of Assisi in Ecstasy (Caravaggio)

revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Saint Francis of Assisi in Ecstasy-Caravaggio (c.1595).jpg | title=Saint Francis of Assisi in Ecstasy | other_language_1 = Italian | other_title_1 = San Francesco in estasi | artist=Caravaggio | image_size = 354px | year=c. 1595 | medium=Oil on canvas | height_metric=92.5 | width_metric=127.8 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=Hartford, Connecticut | museum=Wadsworth Atheneum }} '''''Saint Francis of Assisi in Ecstasy''''' (or ''The Ecstasy of Saint Francis'') is a painting by the Italian Baroque master [[Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio]]. It is held in the [[Wadsworth Atheneum|Wadsworth Atheneum, Hartford, Connecticut]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20060515062933/http://www.wadsworthatheneum.org/view/european-paint-sculpture.php?art_work_index=9 Saint Francis of Assisi in Ecstasy - Notes at Wadsworth Atheneum website] The painting was the first of Caravaggio's religious canvasses, and is thought to date from 1595, when he had recently entered the household of [[Cardinal Francesco Maria Del Monte]]. It was presumably painted at the behest of Del Monte, and is thought to be one of the first paintings done by the artist as "Del Monte's painter", as he is believed to have described himself over the next few years while living in [[Palazzo Madama]]. It shows [[Saint Francis of Assisi]] (the Cardinal's name-saint) at the moment of receiving the signs of the [[Stigmata]], the wounds left in Christ's body by the Crucifixion. The story is told by one of Francis' companions, [[Brother Leo]]. In 1224 Francis retired to the wilderness with a small number of his followers to contemplate God. On the mountainside at night Brother Leo saw a six-winged [[seraph]] (one of the higher Orders of angels) come down to Francis in answer to the saint's prayer that he might know both Christ's suffering and His love:
All of a sudden there was a dazzling light. It was as though the heavens were exploding and splashing forth all their glory in millions of waterfalls of colours and stars. And in the centre of that bright whirlpool was a core of blinding light that flashed down from the depths of the sky with terrifying speed until suddenly it stopped, motionless and sacred, above a pointed rock in front of Francis. It was a fiery figure with wings, nailed to a cross of fire. Two flaming wings rose straight upward, two others opened out horizontally, and two more covered the figure. And the wounds in the hands and feet and heart were blazing rays of blood. The sparkling features of the Being wore an expression of supernatural beauty and grief. It was the face of Jesus, and Jesus spoke. Then suddenly streams of fire and blood shot from His wounds and pierced the hands and feet of Francis with nails and his heart with the stab of a lance. As Francis uttered a mighty shout of joy and pain, the fiery image impressed itself into his body, as into a mirrored reflection of itself, with all its love, its beauty, and its grief. And it vanished within him. Another cry pierced the air. Then, with nails and wounds through his body, and with his soul and spirit aflame, Francis sank down, unconscious, in his blood.[http://www.franciscanfriarstor.com/stfrancis/stf_stigmata_of_st_francis_articles.htm St. Francis Receives the Stigmata - Brother Leo's account] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20061020184834/http://www.franciscanfriarstor.com/stfrancis/stf_stigmata_of_st_francis_articles.htm |date=2006-10-20 }}
[[Image:Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio - St. Francis in Ecstasy (detail) - WGA04080.jpg|thumb|200px|left|''Saint Francis of Assisi in Ecstasy'' (detail).]]Caravaggio's painting is less dramatic than the account given by Leo - the six-winged seraph is replaced by a two-winged [[angel]], and there is none of the violent confrontation described by Leo - no streams of fire, no pools of blood, no shouts or fiery images of Christ. Just the gentle-seeming angel, bulking far larger than the unconscious saint, and Francis' companions in the middle distance, almost invisible in the darkness. The subject had been a popular one ever since the 13th century: [[Giotto]] treated it about 1290, and [[Giovanni Bellini]] painted a famous version about 1480-85. Caravaggio's version is much more intimate and marks a sharp change of key: the saint, who has the features of Del Monte, seems to sink back peacefully into the arms of a boy (who bears a marked resemblance to the boy in ''[[Boy Peeling a Fruit]]'' and to the winged Cupid on the far left of ''[[The Musicians (Caravaggio)|The Musicians]]'', and even more to the boy being cheated in ''[[Cardsharps]]'') wearing a sheet and some stage-prop wings. There is very little to indicate the subject beyond the saint's Franciscan robe - no sign of the Stigmata, or blood, except the wound in his heart, nor of the fearsome seraph. Yet the atmosphere remains genuinely spiritual, the two figures lit by an unearthly effulgence in the dark night-time landscape where strange glimmerings flicker on the horizon. The scene is at once real and unreal. Del Monte kept it till the end of his life, and several copies went into circulation and were greatly valued. ==Footnotes== {{reflist}} {{Caravaggio}} {{Francis of Assisi}} [[Category:1590s paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Caravaggio]] [[Category:Religious paintings]] [[Category:Angels in art]] [[Category:Paintings of Francis of Assisi]]

A '''technical advisor''' is an individual who is an expert in a particular field of [[wiktionary:knowledge|knowledge]], hired to provide detailed information and advice to people working in that field. For example, a construction company might hire a technical expert in fluid dynamics to advise them if seeking to move a small water course or a company operating in [[adventure education]] will frequently hire technical experts to ensure that their policies and procedures are robust enough to handle the hazards they are going to face.
==Film and television== [[Movie director|Movie]] or [[television director]]s, will often hire a technical advisor to ensure that a complicated area is portrayed accurately in the production. For example, a director for a show involving [[combat]] [[aviation]] might hire one or more current or former combat [[Aviator|pilots]] to serve as technical advisors. Similarly, a [[historical period|period]] movie may include one or more [[historian]]s of the period, or eyewitnesses if possible, for the same purpose.
Technical advisors typically answer to the director. Their expertise adds realism both to the [[acting]] and to the [[Setting (fiction)|setting]] of a movie. Some advisors for military movies have been known to run miniature [[recruit training|boot camp]]s to give [[actor]]s a first-hand experience of a [[wiktionary:military|military]] setting. Captain [[Dale Dye]] is a noted technical advisor and provider of military training for actors through his [[Warriors, Inc.]]. The [[US Army]] has often provided technical advisors to [[war film]]s. [[Nipo T. Strongheart]] was a noted technical advisor on several movies dealing with [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]].<ref name=Hearne2013>{{cite book|author=Joanna Hearne|title=Native Recognition: Indigenous Cinema and the Western|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xJ9z36n4ps8C&pg=PA78|date=25 January 2013|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=978-1-4384-4399-7|pages=78, 107}}</ref><ref name="Strongheart1954">{{cite journal | last = Strongheart | first = Nipo T. | date = Autumn 1954 | title = History in Hollywood | journal = The Wisconsin Magazine of History | volume = 38 | issue = 1 | pages = 10–16, 41–46 | jstor = 4632754}}</ref>
The [[British Army]] have supplied their own brand of technical military advisors to the film industry. [http://www.kftv.com/news/2016/08/24/screen-action-filming-with-the-military Paul Biddiss] is one such expert, who has built on a long military career to advise on a multitude of high-profile films and TV series.
Technical advisors who have become actors include [[George Kennedy]] (an Army advisor to the ''[[The Phil Silvers Show|Sgt. Bilko]]'' [[television show]]) and [[John Dierkes]] (an accountant working for the [[U.S. Treasury]], who provided technical assistance to the makers of ''[[To the Ends of the Earth]]''). A former [[child actor]], [[Frank Coghlan Jr]], enlisted in the [[U.S. Navy]], and later became an advisor to Hollywood on Navy-themed films.<ref>Coghlan, Frank ''They Still Call Me Junior'' McFarland & Co 1993</ref>
[[R. Lee Ermey]], a former U.S. Marine who became a technical advisor on several [[Vietnam War]] films lensed in the [[Philippines]] became a lead actor in [[Stanley Kubrick]]'s ''[[Full Metal Jacket]]'' as well as an advisor. Ermey said "A technical advisor must be a salesman. He's got to be able to sell the producer-director on his way of doing things"<ref name="Smith">Smith, Larry ''The Few and the Proud: Marine Corps Drill Instructors in Their Own Words'' 2006 W.W. Norton & Co</ref>{{rp|158}} Ermey told of battles with Kubrick over realism, and what could be shown onscreen and be appreciated by a cinema audience. Ermey lost battles over such items as a recruit having concealed a fully loaded magazine in his footlocker rather than a few stray rounds, and the way Marine Corps Drill Instructors hit recruits in the solar plexus rather than slapping their faces. Ermey won over Kubrick in other points of Marine Corps decorum.<ref name="Smith"/>{{rp|159}}

Nathaniel Warren }} The ''' Crucifucks''' were a [[Lansing, Michigan|Lansing]], [[Michigan]]-based [[punk band]] formed in 1981.{{cite web|last=McPheeters |first=Sam |url=http://www.viceland.com/int/v16n1/htdocs/the-troublemakers-515.php?country= |title=The Troublemaker | VICE |publisher=Viceland.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-22}} They were noted for their political agitation, provocative lyrics, and unusually shrill vocals by band leader [[Doc Corbin Dart]]. [[Dead Kennedys]] vocalist [[Jello Biafra]] signed them to his independent [[Alternative Tentacles]] label. Other members of the original line up included Dart's cousin Joe on guitar, Scott Fagersten on bass, and drummer [[Steve Shelley]], who went on to play with [[Sonic Youth]]. ==History== The band's debut [[Vinyl record|LP]] ''[[The Crucifucks (album)|The Crucifucks]]''—recorded in 1984 and released in 1985 on [[Jello Biafra]]'s [[Alternative Tentacles]] [[record label|label]]. ''[[Wisconsin (album)|Wisconsin]]'' followed in 1987, also on Alternative Tentacles. Between that album and 1996's ''L.D. Eye'', Dart recorded two solo projects, ''Patricia'', on Alternative Tentacles in 1990, and ''Black Tuesday'', a self-released cassette, in 1991. After a long hiatus, Doc released an album entitled "The Messiah" on Crustacean Records in 2004. The moniker he used for this album is "26".[http://www.punknews.org/article/11164/the-crucifucks-doc-dart-returns-with-new-record The Crucifucks' Doc Dart returns with new record] A Crucifucks [[compilation album]] entitled ''[[Our Will Be Done]]'' was issued in 1992, combining the band's first two LPs with a non-LP song, "Annual Report," also featured on [[Maximum Rock 'n' Roll]]'s compilation ''Welcome To 1984''. A picture of a Philadelphia police officer posing as shot—originally part of a public relations campaign [http://www.theroc.org/updates/crucifu2.htm Big Victory For Alternative Tentacles Records] to obtain wage concessions from the city [http://www.theroc.org/updates/crucifux.htm PHILADELPHIA POLICE GET $2.2 MILLION JUDGEMENT AGAINST ALTERNATIVE TENTACLES RECORDS]—was used on the album's back cover. Four years later, its discovery by the Philadelphia Fraternal Order of Police led to a lawsuit against the Crucifucks, which was eventually dismissed.[http://www.mrl.nott.ac.uk/~dxl/reviews/NARS/Vol3/tentacles.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926230939/http://www.mrl.nott.ac.uk/~dxl/reviews/NARS/Vol3/tentacles.html |date=September 26, 2007 }} According to Dart: the Crucifucks never "officially" broke up, but rather drifted apart due to a variety of reasons. By the mid 1990s, Dart had formed a new group called The L.D. Eye. When the group had prepared a full-length record, Alternative Tentacles agreed to release it under the stipulation that it be credited to The Crucifucks. Thus, the group changed its name to The Crucifucks, "reuniting" the band (although no former members other than Dart were involved with The L.D. Eye) and used their former moniker as the record title. ''The L.D. Eye'' was released in 1996. The band played a number of concerts during this period, including a 1998 performance at Alternative Tentacles' twentieth anniversary party at the [[Great American Music Hall]] in [[San Francisco]], [[California]], before sinking back into inactivity. The band was known for its anti-authoritarian lyrics, often rife with obscure and perverse humor. The band sought to go beyond the pale in terms of lyrical content, attempting to be as offensive as possible. Many of their other songs are similarly blunt, attacking the American government, American culture in general, and religion, particularly Christianity. As recently as 2006, Dart has begun identifying himself by the name ''26'' (dropping his entire given name of Doc Corbin Dart) and renounces swear words, such as his former group's moniker. ==Discography== *''[[The Crucifucks (album)|The Crucifucks]]'' - 1985 *''[[Wisconsin (album)|Wisconsin]]'' - 1987 *''[[Our Will Be Done]]'' - 1992 *''[[L.D. Eye]]'' - 1996 == External links == * [http://alternativetentacles.com/bandinfo.php?band=crucifucks Crucifucks Biography] at the [[Alternative Tentacles]] website.[http://alternativetentacles.com/bandinfo.php?band=crucifucks Alternative Tentacles - Bands] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Kk84_GKZvUk video] Live in Akron, OH 1983[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Kk84_GKZvUk YouTube - Crucifucks live @ the Dale (Akron OH) 1983 (part 2/3)] == References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Crucifucks, The}} [[Category:Alternative Tentacles artists]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 1981]] [[Category:Hardcore punk groups from Michigan]] [[Category:Political music]] [[Category:Punk rock groups from Michigan]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Use South African English|date=December 2015}} {{about|the satirical painting by South African artist Brett Murray|the novel by James Herbert|The Spear}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file = The_Spear_-_a_portrait_of_Jacob_Zuma,_by_Brett_Murray.jpg | alt=See adjacent text. | image_size=250px | title=The Spear | artist=[[Brett Murray]] | year=2010<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newzimbabwe.com/opinion-8058-Why+Zumas+Spear+should+stay+up/opinion.aspx |title=Why Zuma's Spear should stay up |publisher=Newzimbabwe.com |date=23 May 2012 |accessdate=2012-07-26}}</ref>| type=[[Acrylic Paint|Acrylic]] on [[canvas]] | height_metric=185 | width_metric=140 | height_imperial=72.8 | width_imperial=55 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Johannesburg]] | museum=[[Goodman Gallery]] }} '''''The Spear''''' is a painting by [[Cape Town]]-based South African artist, [[Brett Murray]]. It depicts South African President [[Jacob Zuma]] in a pose reminiscent of [[Vladimir Lenin|Lenin]], with his genitals exposed.<ref>{{cite web|last=Govender|first=Peroshni|title=Presidential penis portrait riles S. Africa's ANC|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE84H07820120518|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=19 May 2012}}</ref> The painting triggered a defamation lawsuit by Zuma's party, the [[African National Congress]] (ANC), and was vandalised on 22 May 2012.
== Exhibition == Prior to its being vandalised, ''The Spear'' was shown at the Goodman Gallery in [[Johannesburg]], South Africa. The painting featured as one of the pieces of artist Brett Murray's ''Hail to the Thief II'' exhibition, which commenced on 10 May 2012.<ref name=Goodman/> Inspiration is understood to have been drawn from the [[Viktor Semyonovich Ivanov]]'s poster ''Lenin Lived, Lenin is Alive, Lenin Will Live''.<ref>{{cite web|title=The painting of President Zuma|url=http://inside-politics.org/2012/05/17/the-painting-of-president-zuma/|work=www.inside-politics.org|accessdate=7 June 2012}}</ref> The exhibition features various pieces that are critical of South Africa's ruling party, the ANC, showcasing sculptures and images that suggest [[corruption]] and bad governance.<ref name=Goodman>{{cite web|title=Goodman Gallery - Hail to the Thief II|url=http://www.goodman-gallery.com/exhibitions/265|publisher=Goodman Gallery|accessdate=19 May 2012}}</ref> Murray's works in the exhibition also include modifying ANC liberation struggle posters and flyers from the [[Apartheid]] era, some displaying the text "Amandla, we demand Chivas, BMWs and bribes".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iol.co.za/saturday-star/it-s-staying-up-1.1302261 |title=It’s staying up! |author=Sameer Naik and Kashiefa Ajam |date=22 May 2012 |work=The Saturday Star |accessdate=22 May 2012}}</ref>
== Public perception of Jacob Zuma == Zuma has often been the centre of scandal and ridicule, due to his polygamous lifestyle with many wives and girlfriends,<ref>{{cite web|title=Jacob Zuma - "Polygamy is part of my culture"|url=http://www.rnw.nl/africa/article/jacob-zuma-polygamy-part-my-culture|publisher=Radio Netherlands Worldwide|accessdate=19 May 2012}}</ref> and a comment he made during his 2006 [[Jacob Zuma rape trial|rape trial]] that showering after sex would minimise the risk of contracting [[HIV]].<ref>{{cite news|title=SA's Zuma 'showered to avoid HIV'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/4879822.stm|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=19 May 2012}}</ref> His lifestyle has made him the target of well-known cartoonist [[Zapiro]], who frequently depicts Zuma with a shower on his head, ridiculing the statements he made during his trial.<ref>{{cite web|last=Nicolaides|first=Gia|title=Zapiro revives showerhead|url=http://news.iafrica.com/sa/574737.html|publisher=iafrica.com|accessdate=19 May 2012}}</ref> Zapiro was also sued for defamation by the ANC, with a hearing expected in October 2012.<ref name=BBC185 /> These public perceptions of Zuma provided part of the basis for Brett Murray's painting.<ref name=BBC185>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-18115724 |title=Jacob Zuma painting: ANC to sue South Africa's Brett Murray |date=18 May 2012 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=22 May 2012}}</ref>
Zapiro added fuel to the fire by doing his own version of the painting, replacing the genitals with a showerhead.<ref name=Zapiro185>{{cite web |url=http://www.zapiro.com/cartoon/890737-120520st |title=Published in Sunday Times on 20 May 2012 |date=20 May 2012 |publisher=Zapiro |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> Another appeared two days later, ridiculing Zuma.<ref name=Zapiro186>{{cite web |url=http://www.zapiro.com/cartoon/892612-120522tt |title=120522tt - President Zuma outraged at Brett Murray's Painting - Spear of the Nation |date=22 May 2012 |publisher=Zapiro |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref>
== ANC response ==
Owner and director of the Goodman Gallery, Liza Essers, said that she received a telephone call on Sunday, 13 May 2012 from special advisor to the minister of arts and culture Mduduzi Mbata seeking to clarify her thoughts on the exhibition, after it had been reviewed in the newspaper [[City Press (South Africa)|''City Press'']], along with a photograph of ''The Spear''. During the brief conversation she invited him to visit the gallery the following Tuesday, but he never kept the appointment.<ref name=AiA>{{cite web|last=Dubin|first=Steven|title=Liza Essers, Gallery Owner, on the Show that Scandalized South Africa|url=http://www.artinamericamagazine.com/news-opinion/conversations/2012-06-05/liza-essers-brent-murray-goodman-gallery/|work=Art in America|publisher=Art in America|accessdate=7 June 2012|date=5 June 2012}}</ref>
The ANC issued a press release on 17 May 2012 expressing outrage about the painting and their intention to apply to the High Court to have it removed, this being reiterated by attorneys representing the ANC and Jacob Zuma in an email sent to Essers the same day.<ref name=AiA/> The painting drew strong condemnation from ANC rulers and various religious groups, who found the painting 'obscene' and 'vulgar'.<ref name="mosomane1">{{cite web|last=Mosomane|first=Phuti|title=Zuma painting against Ubuntu, African morality, culture|url=http://www.thenewage.co.za/Detail.aspx?news_id=51152&cat_id=1007|publisher=The New Age|accessdate=19 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150526184457/http://www.thenewage.co.za/Detail.aspx?news_id=51152&cat_id=1007|archivedate=26 May 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> A leader of the Nazareth Baptist Church called for the artist to be stoned to death.<ref name=AiA/> The ANC also demanded that the image be taken down from the [[City Press (South Africa)|''City Press'']]' website. ANC spokesperson Jackson Mthembu said of the painting, "The African National Congress is extremely disturbed and outraged by the distasteful and indecent manner in which Brett Murray and the Goodman Gallery in Johannesburg is displaying the person of comrade President Jacob Zuma".<ref>{{cite web|title=ANC to go to court over Zuma painting|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/Politics/ANC-to-go-to-court-over-Zuma-painting-20120517|publisher=News24.com|accessdate=19 May 2012}}</ref> Zuma responded to the artwork by saying that it painted him as "a philanderer and a womaniser".<ref>{{cite news|title=Painting makes me a womaniser - Zuma|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/painting-makes-me-a-womaniser-zuma-1.1300191|accessdate=20 May 2012|newspaper=IOL.co.za|date=20 May 2012}}</ref>
In response to the impending legal action, gallery spokesperson Lara Koseff said its lawyers had responded that it would stay until the show was over, citing censorship concerns as central to the decision to allow the exhibition to continue.<ref name="mosomane1"/> The [[African National Congress Women's League|ANC Women's League]] has also demanded that the exhibition be halted, and all instances of the image be removed from the internet.<ref>{{cite news|title=Painting violates president's integrity, says ANCWL|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2012/05/19/painting-violates-president-s-integrity-says-ancwl|accessdate=19 May 2012|newspaper=Times Live|date=19 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Stephen|first=Grootes|title=Zuma portrait saga goes to court|url=http://www.ewn.co.za/en/2012/05/19/Zuma%20portrait%20saga%20goes%20to%20court.aspx|accessdate=19 May 2012|newspaper=Eyewitness News|date=19 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130602173211/http://ewn.co.za/en/2012/05/19/Zuma%20portrait%20saga%20goes%20to%20court.aspx|archivedate=2 June 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Brett Murray said that his painting had not been intended maliciously, but as "an attempt at humorous satire of political power and patriarchy within the context of other artworks in the exhibition and within the broader context of South African discourse".<ref name=N24Defaced />
In the first day of legal proceedings, the representative for the ANC, Gcina Malindi, began sobbing and was unable to proceed, causing the process to be adjorned and postponed and the television coverage of the event was suppressed. Later, the ANC sought to drop proceedings.<ref>{{cite news|title=Zuma lawyers tears as court hears rude painting case|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-18186692|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=BBC News with video|date=24 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=ANC advocate sobs in court|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/ANC-advocate-sobs-in-court-20120524|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=News24|date=24 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title='South Africa court hears Jacob Zuma obscene painting case|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-18182318|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=BBC News|date=24 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Conway-Smith|first=Erin|title=Jacob Zuma The Spear painting case postponed indefinitely|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/africa/south-africa/120524/the-spear-jacob-zuma-painting-court-case-anc-lawyer|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=GlobalPost|date=24 May 2012}}</ref>
=== Consequences === The ANC's public condemnation of the painting brought widespread local and international attention to the painting, where otherwise it may have remained a relatively obscure piece of work. For this reason, the action and subsequent fall-out has been characterised as an example of the [[Streisand effect]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Just Hanging Out|url=http://6000.co.za/just-hanging-out/|publisher=6000 Miles from Civilization|accessdate=19 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Mahere|first=Fadzayi|title=Why Zuma's Spear should stay up|url=http://www.newzimbabwe.com/opinion-8058-Why+Zumas+Spear+should+stay+up/opinion.aspx|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=New Zimbabwe|date=23 May 2012}}</ref> Subsequently, ''The Spear'' has been featured in editorials and news features in all forms of traditional and digital media.
Former ANC leader [[Oliver Tambo]]’s daughter Tselane Tambo was of the opinion that Zuma deserved Murray’s portrayal of him. She wrote on a social networking site, “Do the poor enjoy poverty? Do the unemployed enjoy hopelessness? Do those who can’t get housing enjoy homelessness? He must get over it. No one is having a good time. He should inspire the reverence he craves. This portrait is what he inspired. Shame neh!”.<ref>{{cite news|title=Video: Zuma’s Spear painting sabotage|url=http://www.thesouthafrican.com/news/spear-today-gone-tomorrow.htm|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=The South African .com|date=22 May 2012}}</ref>
The media boycott of ''City Press'' by the ANC and various public figures led to the newspaper eventually removing the painting from its website on 28 May 2012.<ref>{{cite news|last=de Waal|first=Mandy|title=City Press buckles to ANC demands - and threats|url=http://dailymaverick.co.za/article/2012-05-28-city-press-buckles-to-anc-demands-and-threats|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=Daily Maverick|date=28 May 2012}}</ref> The paper's editor-in-chief Ferial Haffajee cited several reasons for this decision, including violent threats made to her team by those supporting the boycott.{{or|date=July 2012}}
=== Media boycott === After ''City Press'' repeatedly refused to remove an image of the painting off their website, the ANC called upon its members and sympathisers to boycott placing advertising in, and buying of, the weekly paper. A statement released by the ANC said: "Their refusal to remove this portrait from their website and their controlled social media is a clear indication that this newspaper does not belong to our shared democratic dispensation and values." Responding to the boycott, ''City Press'' editor-in-chief [[Ferial Haffajee]] described Nzimande's call for a boycott of the paper as "deeply disturbing".<ref>{{cite news|title=Boycott 'immoral' ''City Press'', ANC urges|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/Politics/Boycott-City-Press-the-paragon-of-immorality-ANC-20120524-2|accessdate=25 May 2012|newspaper=News24.co.za|date=25 May 2012}}</ref>
The ANC was criticised by the South African National Editors' Forum (SANEF),<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=David|title=Zuma genitals row escalates as ANC calls for boycott of newspaper|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/may/25/zuma-genitals-row-anc-newspaper-boycott|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=25 May 2012}}</ref> which said "While we recognise the right of the ANC to advise members on how to exercise their consumer decisions, the call for a boycott of a newspaper is tantamount to intimidation and abuse of power ... This kind of behaviour is unbecoming of a party that functions in an open democratic stage and especially one which leads the national government."<ref>{{cite web|title=Sanef alarmed at call by the ANC to boycott City Press Newspaper (Press release)|url=http://sanef.org.za/news/entry/sanef_alarmed_at_the_call_by_the_anc_to_boycott_city_press_newspaper/|work=South African National Editors' Forum website|accessdate=7 June 2012|date=24 May 2012}}</ref> The boycott of City Press was further condemned by the [[International Press Institute]] (IPI),<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2012/may/28/southafrica-press-freedom South African newspaper defies ANC boycott call]</ref> and by 28 May, ten days after the newspaper printed the painting for the first time, opinions in the ANC had divided with several senior members opposing the boycott.<ref>{{cite news|last=Greenslade|first=Roy|title=South African newspaper defies ANC boycott call|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2012/may/28/southafrica-press-freedom|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=Greenslade Blog - The Guardian|date=28 May 2012}}</ref>
== Defacement == On the morning of 22 May 2012, two men entered the gallery during visiting hours, and defaced the painting - first by painting a red cross over the depiction of Zuma's face and genitals, and then by smearing black paint over the canvas. The two men — Barend la Grange and Lowie Mabokela<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/global/2012/05/painting-south-african-presidents-penis-defaced/52698/ |title=Painting of South African President's Penis Defaced |author=Adam Martin |date=23 May 2012 |work=The Atlantic |accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> — were arrested by security officials. This defacement took place whilst court proceedings brought on by the ANC around the right to censor the image were underway.<ref name=N24Defaced>{{cite news|last=Pasley-Banks|first=Carrin|title=Zuma painting defaced at Goodman Gallery|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Zuma-painting-defaced-at-Goodman-Gallery-20120522|accessdate=22 May 2012|publisher=News24|date=22 May 2012|quote=The controversial painting depicting President Jacob Zuma with his genitals exposed was defaced by two men at the Goodman Gallery in Johannesburg on Tuesday.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Zuma 'penis painting' defaced|url=http://news.iafrica.com/sa/795807.html|accessdate=22 May 2012|newspaper=iafrica.com|date=22 May 2012}}</ref>
The way in which the two men were arrested also drew criticism: Barend la Grange was arrested without any apparent violence, while Lowie Mabokela was head-butted and thrown to the ground.<ref>{{cite news|last=Herskovitz|first=Jon|title=South Africa painting debate exposes racial rifts|url=http://mobile.reuters.com/article/oddlyEnoughNews/idUSBRE84M04O20120524|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=Reuters|date=24 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Gallery security guard arrested over Zuma painting incident|url=http://www.sowetanlive.co.za/news/2012/05/23/gallery-security-guard-arrested-over-zuma-painting-incident|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=Sowetan Live|date=23 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=David|title=Zuma portrait court case reopens South Africa's wounds from apartheid era|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/may/24/spear-zuma-portrait-court-apartheid|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=24 May 2012}}</ref>
== Classification == On 22 May 2012, the [[Films and Publications Act, 1996|Film and Publication Board (FPB)]] of South Africa announced that a team of five classifiers had been sent to assess ''The Spear'',<ref name=fpb20120522>{{cite web |author=Film and Publication Board (South Africa) |title=FPB Classification of 'The Spear' Artwork as Displayed at the Goodman Gallery (PDF document) |work=FPB.gov.za |url=http://www.fpb.gov.za/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_view&gid=163&tmpl=component&format=raw&Itemid=103 |publisher=Film and Publication Board |location=Centurion, Gauteng, South Africa |date=22 May 2012 |accessdate=1 June 2012 }}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> following specific complaints to the FPB, which is the statutory body responsible for classifying, and applying age ratings and content advisories to, works published or distributed in South Africa,<ref name=fpbzaabout>{{cite web |author=Film and Publication Board (South Africa) |title=Film and Publication Board Profile |work=FPB.org.za |url=http://www.fpb.org.za/profile-fpb |publisher=Film and Publication Board |location=Centurion, Gauteng, South Africa |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref> including films, computer games, images of all kinds, and printed publications;<ref name=fpb20120601>{{cite web |author=Film and Publication Board (South Africa) |title=FPB Classification of 'The Spear' Artwork (PDF document) |work=FPB.gov.za |url=http://www.fpb.gov.za/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_view&gid=169&tmpl=component&format=raw&Itemid=103 |publisher=Film and Publication Board |location=Centurion, Gauteng, South Africa |date=1 June 2012 |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref>{{rp|1, 3}} however, "Only pornographic publications need to be passed by the FPB before they are released on the market" while others are considered based on "complaints received from the public regarding specific publications",<ref name=fpbclassification>{{cite web |author=Film and Publication Board (South Africa) |title=Classification of Films, Games and Publications |work=FPB.org.za |url=http://www.fpb.org.za/classifications |publisher=Film and Publication Board |location=Centurion, Gauteng, South Africa |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref> and the [[Films and Publications Act, 1996|FPB's]] jurisdiction specifically excludes newspapers<ref name="fpb20120601" />{{rp|3}}<ref name=timeslive20120529a>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association |title='We don't rule over City Press', says FPB |work=TimesLive.co.za |url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/local/2012/05/29/we-don-t-rule-over-city-press-says-fpb |publisher=Times Live |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=29 May 2012 |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=iol20120601>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association |title=Board explains Spear 16N rating |work=IOL.co.za |url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/special-features/the-zuma-era/board-explains-spear-16n-rating-1.1309795 |publisher=Independent Online |location=Cape Town, South Africa |date=1 June 2012 |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> and the broadcast media,<ref name="timeslive20120529a"/><ref name=fpbzahome>{{cite web |author=Film and Publication Board (South Africa) |title=Home |work=FPB.org.za |url=http://www.fpb.org.za/ |publisher=Film and Publication Board |location=Centurion, Gauteng, South Africa |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref> which are regulated by separate entities. For this reason, the FPB proceedings could only consider the painting itself, its display by the gallery, and its publication or possible publication on websites or in other venues subject to FPB jurisdiction; and could not address the publication of images of it by newspapers or broadcasters.<ref name="fpb20120601"/>{{rp|3}}<ref name="timeslive20120529a"/><ref name="iol20120601"/> During the classification proceedings, there were allegations that the FPB was acting outside its statutory remit,<ref name=timeslive20120529b>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association |title=Board has no right to classify "The Spear": lawyer |work=TimesLive.co.za |url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/scitech/2012/05/29/board-has-no-right-to-classify-the-spear-lawyer |publisher=Times Live |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=29 May 2012 |accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> and that specific members had made statements or asked questions implying that it was entitled to censor political opinions and restrict freedom of the press.<ref name=mg20120530>{{cite news |first=Phillip |last=de Wet |title='The Spear': It's classified, and now up to the ombud |work=mg.co.za |url=http://mg.co.za/article/2012-05-30-fpb-its-our-duty-to-classify-the-spear-and-suppress-criticism/ |publisher=Mail & Guardian |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=30 May 2012 |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref>
On 1 June 2012, the FPB announced that the classifiers assigned to 'The Spear' had rejected a complainant's call for the painting to be rated X18<ref name="fpb20120601"/>{{rp|5}} (placing it within the category of legal [[pornography|pornographic]] works that must "be passed by the FPB before they are released on the market",<ref name="fpbclassification"/> and that may be distributed only by licensed distributors, who are required to obtain proof of age<ref name=fpbzafpact2009>{{cite journal |author=Government of the Republic of South Africa |title=Regulations - Film and Publication Act 3 of 2009 |journal=Government Gazette, Republic of South Africa |volume=537 |issue=33026 |url=http://www.fpb.org.za/profile-fpb/2012-05-23-04-21-16/doc_details/108-regulations-fpb-amendment-act-3-of-2009 |publisher=Government Printer |location=Pretoria, South Africa |date=15 March 2010 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref>{{rp|19}}), but had decided on a 16N rating for the original, undefaced and uncensored, painting, meaning that measures should be put in place to prevent access to it and to images of it by those under the age of sixteen, and to advise "sensitive adult viewers" over sixteen that it contains nudity (but not explicit sexual content, which would have been designated by an S in the rating).<ref name="fpb20120601"/>{{rp|5}}<ref name="iol20120601"/><ref name=mg20120601>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association |title='The Spear' gets 16N rating |work=mg.co.za |url=http://mg.co.za/article/2012-06-01-the-spear-gets-16n-rating |publisher=Mail & Guardian |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=1 June 2012 |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=timeslive20120601>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association |title=Censors rate Spear 16N for nudity |work=TimesLive.co.za |url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/local/2012/06/01/censors-rate-spear-16n-for-nudity |publisher=Times Live |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=1 June 2012 |accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> In its press statement announcing the classification, the FPB referred at length to its statutory authority and responsibilities, in particular its role in "promoting the safety of children";<ref name="fpb20120601"/>{{rp|1}} and explicitly denied that it had been influenced by political figures or had acted beyond its jurisdiction, saying that "We believe that reports to the contrary have been specifically designed to defame the Film and Publication Board, question its integrity, competence, credibility as well as formulate as a reality the false notion that the state seeks to silence and censor the media by all means possible and with total disregard for accepted procedures and principles".<ref name="fpb20120601"/>{{rp|3}} In reply to questions, FPB chief operations officer Mmapula Fisha said that ''The Spear'' differed from other works of art containing nudity, and merited the 16N classification, because "The artwork has forced society to revisit its painful history".<ref name="iol20120601"/> After the classification was announced, the Goodman Gallery was reported to be seeking legal advice, but to have said they "felt it would have a significant impact on freedom of artistic expression",<ref name=iol20120601at18h24>{{cite news |author=South African Press Association |title=Gallery studying ‘Spear’ classification |work=IOL.co.za |url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/gallery-studying-spear-classification-1.1310184 |publisher=Independent Online |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=1 June 2012 |accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> a criticism also made by commentators not involved in the case,<ref name=sabc20120705>{{cite news |author=South African Broadcasting Corporation |title=Artists warned to exercise self-censorship following "The Spear" saga |work=SABC.co.za |url=http://www.sabc.co.za/news/a/fdf12f804b81bf8cac20fe88d736c33c/Artists-warned-to-exercise-self-censorship-following-The-Spear-saga-20120605 |publisher=SABC |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=5 June 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref> while others expressed concern about political censorship.<ref name=polity20120608hamber>{{cite news |first=Brandon |last=Hamber |title=Putting the Presidential pickle in perspective |work=Polity.org.za |url=http://www.polity.org.za/article/putting-the-presidential-pickle-in-perspective-2012-06-08 |publisher=Creamer Media |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=8 June 2012 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref><ref name=citypress20120603editorial>{{cite news |author=City Press Editor |title=FPB decision smacks of censorship |work=Citypress.co.za |url=http://www.citypress.co.za/Opinions/Editorials/FPB-decision-smacks-of-censorship-20120602 |publisher=City Press |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |date=3 June versions of it (Microsoft Word 2007 .docx document) |work=FPB.org.za |url=http://www.fpb.org.za/images/documents/reviewawards/The_Spear_Appeal_Award.docx |publisher=Film and Publication Board Africa) |title=Press Statement on the award in respect of the appeal for the FPB Classification of 'The Spear' painting as displayed at the Goodman Gallery |work=FPB.org.za |url=http://www.fpb.org.za/media-centre-fpb/press-release |publisher=Film and Publication Board |location=Centurion, Gauteng, South Africa |date=10 October 2012 |accessdate=11 October 2012}}</ref> The Appeal Tribunal approved the original Classification Committee's determination that ''The Spear'' should not be classed as [[pornography]],<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|5-7}} but found against the committee, its procedure, and its classification on several grounds, including that the decision had been based on flawed arguments and interpretation of the relevant law;<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|7-11}} that the committee had relied on conclusions for which no evidence had been presented either during the original classification process or to the Appeal Tribunal;<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|13}} that the FPB should not have considered a complaint against the publication of ''The Spear'' in newspapers or on their websites, because the FPB has no jurisdiction over such publications, and should instead have passed complaints against them on to the appropriate regulator;<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|3}} that the committee had wrongly taken upon itself "responsibility for balancing conflicting rights" that properly belonged to the courts, and was beyond the "much narrower mandate [of] the Classification Committee";<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|10-1}} that the FPB had wrongly, and in violation both of the rights of their publishers and of legal principles of procedural fairness, "appeared to extend its ruling to all websites that contained electronic replications of the painting and to all other publications of the painting", rather than restricting its decision to the specific named respondents who had been accorded an opportunity to make representations during the classification process;<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|3-4}} that due weight had not been given to the painting's status as a work of agreed artistic merit enjoying greater statutory protection from both publication and age restrictions;<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|11-3, 7}} that the committee had wrongly deemed nudity ''per se'' to be grounds for considering a work of art "potentially disturbing, harmful, or inappropriate to children";<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|13}} and that the committee had used the system of "restrictive age classifications" designed solely to "protect children" (and not adults) from potentially "disturbing, harmful, or age-inappropriate material" and "from premature exposure to adult experiences"<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|9-11}} in a way that "was not legally permissible" for "the purposes of protecting sensitive viewers or assuaging the sense of indignity felt by some segments of the community"<ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|11}} by effectively restricting adults' access to a published work that was neither illegal nor [[pornography|pornographic]].<ref name="citypress20121010"/><ref name="fpb20121007award" />{{rp|7-11}}
==Comparisons== ''The Spear'' portrait has invited comparison to other satirical pieces, including fellow South African artist [[Ayanda Mabulu|Ayanda Mabulu's]] work, ''{{lang|zu|Ngcono ihlwempu kunesibhanxo sesityebi}}'' (Zulu: "Better poor than a rich puppet"), which depicts various regional and international political figures - including Jacob Zuma - in the nude. The painting received additional attention following the media focus on controversial satirical artworks.<ref>{{cite web|last=Butana|first=Kwanele|title=Cape artist despairs for ‘illiterate’ ANC|url=http://www.iol.co.za/the-star/cape-artist-despairs-for-illiterate-anc-1.1302504|publisher=iol.co.za|accessdate=25 May 2012}}</ref>

(1963-1964) *[[CBS Films]] *[[Viacom]] *[[Paramount Television]] *[[CBS Television Studios|CBS Paramount Television]] *[[CBS Television Distribution]] {{small|(as of 2007)}}}} |runtime = 30 mins. |channel = [[CBS]] |first_aired = {{start date|1958|9|29}} |last_aired = {{end date|1960|9|19}} }} '''''The Texan''''' is a [[Western (genre)|western]] [[Television program|television series]] starring popular [[B movie]] actor [[Rory Calhoun]], which aired on the [[CBS]] [[television network]] from 1958 to 1960. ==Overview== [[File:Rory Calhoun The Texan 1961.JPG|thumb|right|200px|Calhoun as Bill Longley (c. 1960)]] {{further|List of The Texan episodes}} In ''The Texan,'' Calhoun played Bill Longley, a [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] captain from the [[American Civil War]] who on his pinto, Domino, roams the [[Western United States|American West]] but stops to help people in need. A fast gun and the enemy of all lawbreakers, this "Robin Hood of the West" seems to appear nearly everywhere in the post-war years, not just in [[Texas]]. Often the plots center about Longley helping an old friend or a relative of an old friend. Though known as a fearsome gunfighter, the fictional Bill Longley of ''The Texan'' is in no way the real [[Bill Longley (gunfighter)|Bill Longley]]. That Longley killed his first man in 1866, when he was fifteen, and was [[Hanging|hanged]] in 1878 in [[Giddings, Texas|Giddings]] in [[Lee County, Texas|Lee County]] in [[Central Texas]]. A more accurate version of the real Longley is [[Douglas Kennedy (actor)|Douglas Kennedy]]'s rendition in the [[Television syndication|syndicated]] series, ''[[Stories of the Century]]'', starring and narrated by [[Jim Davis (actor)|Jim Davis]], and the first western series to win an [[Emmy Award]].Billy Hathorn, "Roy Bean, Temple Houston, Bill Longley, Ranald Mackenzie, Buffalo Bill, Jr., and the Texas Rangers: Depictions of West Texans in Series Television, 1955 to 1967", ''[[West Texas Historical Association|West Texas Historical Review]]'', Vol. 89 (2013), pp. 110-112 ''The Texan'' offers several multi-part episodes. In a four-parter, Longley portrays the boss of a [[cattle drive]]; in another, a railroad construction supervisor. In still another, Longley pursues the bandit El Sombro in the fictitious corrupt community of Rio Nada. In this episode, [[Barbara Stuart]] makes one of her three appearances as [[Poker Alice]], an unlikely frontier [[Gambling|gambler]], the mother of seven children who had once been a dealer at [[Robert Ford (outlaw)|Bob Ford]]'s [[Western saloon|saloon]] in [[Creede, Colorado]], but lived thereafter primarily in [[Deadwood, South Dakota|Deadwood]] and [[Sturgis, South Dakota]]. Calhoun's then wife, Lita Baron, appeared in several episodes, including a three-parter. ==Production notes== With [[Victor Orsatti]], Calhoun formed Rorvic Productions to co-produce ''The Texan'' in partnership with [[Desilu Productions]], the company founded by [[Lucille Ball]] and her first husband, [[Desi Arnaz]]. Then a neighbor of Orsatti's, Arnaz proposed the idea for ''The Texan''. Episodes were budgeted at $40,000 each, with two segments filmed weekly at Desilu Studios. Despite the name, the program was not filmed in Texas but at Pearl Flats in the [[Mohave Desert]] in [[southern California]]. ''The Texan'' ran for only two seasons but could have been extended for a third had Calhoun been willing to continue. However, he wanted to return to films. In the second half of the second season, ''The Texan'' was preceded on the CBS schedule by [[Kate Smith]]'s return to network television, her unsuccessful ''[[The Kate Smith Show]]''. The first season, sponsored by [[Viceroy (cigarette)|Viceroy]], is considered of better quality because CBS reused in the second season some of the material and footage from the first season. After the 78-episode run, Calhoun returned to starring and co-starring in "B" westerns and making occasional television appearances. [[Louis L'Amour]] wrote teleplays for several episodes, but there were thirty-five writers hired for the series and more than a dozen directors. One of the directors, [[George Archainbaud]], a native of [[Paris]], [[France]], died during the run of ''The Texan''. Other directors were [[Erle C. Kenton]], who began his career in 1914 with [[silent film]]s, and [[Edward Ludwig]], a native of [[Russia]]. ''The Texan'' faced competition in its first season from another western, ''[[The Restless Gun]]'', an [[NBC]] series. Though ''The Restless Gun'' finished in eighth place in the ratings in its first season (1957-1958), ''The Texan'' surpassed it in the 1958-1959 season to finish at #15 while ''The Restless Gun'' fell out of the top 30 and ended its run in 1959. However, ''The Texan'' then also fell out of the top 30 the following season (1959-1960).http://www.classictvhits.com/tvratings/index.htm In the 1960-1961 television season, rebroadcasts of ''The
